pulltitle: fix(security): Remove colons from CSP header
pullsbody: refs: https://github.com/mozilla-services/foxsec/issues/177 Apparently I can't make a two line change without introducing bugs. Fixes errors: ``` Content Security Policy: Couldn’t process unknown directive ‘default-src:’ Content Security Policy: Couldn’t process unknown directive ‘frame-ancestors:’ Content Security Policy: Couldn’t process unknown directive ‘report-uri:’ ``` with #90. Functional Test: - [x] run `./server.js` and open / on this branch and do not get CSP errors
pull_commit_message:
fix(security): Remove colons from CSP header

Fixes errors:

Content Security Policy: Couldn’t process unknown directive ‘default-src:’
Content Security Policy: Couldn’t process unknown directive ‘frame-ancestors:’
Content Security Policy: Couldn’t process unknown directive ‘report-uri:’

should've included this in: #89

refs: https://github.com/mozilla-services/foxsec/issues/177

pullsbody:
In Dockerfile, after COPY package.json, this file is owned by root:root,
however, the user 'app' needs to read it. Add a RUN chown command to
alleviate this.
pull_commit_message:
Fix permission issue in Dockerfile

In Dockerfile, after COPY package.json, this file is owned by root:root,
however, the user 'app' needs to read it. Add a RUN chown command to
alleviate this.
Update browserid-local-verify to latest release

pullsbody:
This is a refactored docker build process. After some research CircleCI has better docker support. This PR should be good for review now. This would be the first project to use CircleCI w/ Cloudops Dockerflow. :)

A few things:
- tested it in mostlygeek/browserid-verifier and the docker container build / test / push works
- cloudops will set up https://docker.hub.com/r/mozilla/browserid-verifier repos + circleCI integration
- CircleCI integration settings should be accessible to anybody with permissions to push to this repo
pull_commit_message: Improve Dockerfile and add CircleCI to build container

pullsbody:
This PR has several changes to get browserid-verifier into Cloudops' Dockerflow model. As a part of the change travis-ci builds, tests and pushes the container to Docker Hub. 

Dockerfile:
- made more cache friendly
- add non priviledged user to run npm and application
- add ENTRYPOINT / CMD
- use node v4.2.4 base container from 0.10

.travis.yml
- Builds, tests and pushes docker containers to dockerhub
- Part of cloudops' new Dockerflow

pulltitle: feat(docker): Dockerfile and README update for basic docker development workflow
pullsbody: I've added a dockerfile and some instructions to README.md explaining how to use Docker to develop and run browserid-verifier. It allows for development with an IDE underneath a running container as one would normally work. This means changes and running the verifier are mostly transparent to normal development. If there are any questions feel free to ask here or in IRC.

pulltitle: Log fields of any object args as part of top-level json log object.
pullsbody:
As noted in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1053959#c9 we currently produce some JSON log lines that contain nested JSON along with other stuff in the "message" field.  For easier handling and PII scrubbing we should ensure that all JSON fields are logged as top-level object properties, even if there's also a string message in the log.

This produces appropriate-looking output for me.  @seanmonstar r?
pull_commit_message: Log fields of any object args as part of top-level json log object.

pulltitle: Fix deprecated argument order in res.json().
pullsbody: Express logs a deprecation warning when using `resp.json(obj, status)` so this fixes things to use the preferred `resp.json(status. obj)`.  @fmarier r?
pull_commit_message: Fix deprecated argument order in res.json().

pulltitle: Log something when sending a 503 due to toobusy.

In a recent tokenserver loadtest, we see 503s from the verifier.  I think this is simply because we're overloading it, but there's nothing in the logs to confirm.  Let's log something when we error out because of toobusy().

@seanmonstar r? since this involves logging stuff, which IIRC you're most familiar with; although I'd be pretty surprised to discover I'm using it wrong here :-)

pulltitle: Fail gracefully if not content-type header is given.
pullsbody:
Clients may not send any content-type header in the verification request.  We should fail, but not like this:

```
{
  "status": "failure",
  "reason": "TypeError: Cannot call method 'indexOf' of undefined"
}
```

This PR does the minimal work necessary to give a descriptive error; it may be more developer-friendly to return an explicit "Missing Content-Type header" message.
pull_commit_message: Fail gracefully if not content-type header is given.
